December 5, 2010: Fiction
CROSS FIRE, by James Patterson. (Little, Brown, $27.99.) Alex Cross
investigates a professional assassination in Washington, and gets a chilling call
from his deadliest adversary.
THE CONFESSION, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $28.95.) A criminal wants to
save an innocent man on death row, but he must convince the authorities he’s
telling the truth.
HELL'S CORNER, by David Baldacci. (Grand Central, $27.99.) Recalled to duty,
Oliver Stone hunts for those responsible for a bomb detonated near the White
House.
CRESCENT DAWN, by Clive Cussler and Dirk Cussler. (Putnam, $27.95.) Dirk
Pitt seeks a tie between a trove of ancient Roman artifacts and a series of mosque
explosions.
FULL DARK, NO STARS, by Stephen King. (Scribner, $27.99.) Four long stories,
light on the supernatural and dealing mostly with grisly human behavior.
THE GIRL WHO KICKED THE HORNET’S NEST, by Stieg Larsson. (Knopf,
$27.95.) The third volume of a trilogy about a Swedish hacker and a journalist.
TOWERS OF MIDNIGHT, by Robert Jordan and Brandon Sanderson. (Tor,
$29.99.) Book 13 of the Wheel of Time fantasy series.
SQUIRREL SEEKS CHIPMUNK, by David Sedaris. (Little, Brown, $21.99.) The
humorist looks at human nature through stories with animals as characters.
I STILL DREAM ABOUT YOU, by Fannie Flagg. (Random House, $26.) A former
Miss Alabama’s radical plan to solve all her problems keeps getting interrupted.
FALL OF GIANTS, by Ken Follett. (Dutton, $36.) Five interrelated families from
five countries are caught in the upheavals of World War I and the Russian
Revolution.
THE HELP, by Kathryn Stockett. (Amy Einhorn/Putnam, $24.95.) A young
Southern white woman and two black maids.
AMERICAN ASSASSIN, by Vince Flynn. (Atria, $27.99.) In the wake of the
Lockerbie bombing, Mitch Rapp takes on his first antiterrorist assignment.
SAFE HAVEN, by Nicholas Sparks. (Grand Central, $25.99.) The arrival of a
mysterious young woman in a small North Carolina town raises questions about
her past.
IN THE COMPANY OF OTHERS, by Jan Karon. (Viking, $27.95.) In Ireland, the
Episcopal priest Tim Kavanagh finds an old journal that could solve a crime.
December 5, 2010
Non-Fiction
DECISION POINTS, by George W. Bush. (Crown, $35.) The former president’s
memoir discusses his Christianity and the end of his drinking; his relationships
with members of his family; and his decisions on 9/11, Iraq and Katrina.
UNBROKEN, by Laura Hillenbrand. (Random House, $27.) An Olympic runner’s
story of survival as a prisoner of the Japanese in World War II.
DECODED, by Jay-Z. (Spiegel & Grau, $35.) The hip-hop star leads a narrative
journey through his lyrics and his life.
LIFE, by Keith Richards with James Fox. (Little, Brown, $29.99.) The Rolling
Stones guitarist’s revealing autobiography is also a portrait of the era when rock ’n’
roll came of age, with the music itself as the book’s core.
AUTOBIOGRAPHY OF MARK TWAIN, VOL. 1, by Mark Twain. (University of
California, $34.95.) In his autobiography, published unexpurgated for the first time,
Twain is pointedly political and willing to play the angry prophet.
BROKE, by Glenn Beck and Kevin Balfe. (Threshold/Mercury Radio Arts, $29.99.)
The Fox News host’s plan for fixing the country’s financial woes.
I REMEMBER NOTHING, by Nora Ephron. (Knopf, $22.95.) Reflections on age
and memory, from the author of “I Feel Bad About My Neck.”
CLEOPATRA, by Stacy Schiff. (Little, Brown, $29.99.) A biography of the last
queen of ancient Egypt.
EARTH (THE BOOK), by Jon Stewart, David Javerbaum, Rory Albanese, Steve
Bodow and Josh Lieb. (Grand Central, $27.99.) A visitor’s guide to the human
race, presented by "The Daily Show."
ALL THE DEVILS ARE HERE, by Bethany McLean and Joe Nocera.
(Portfolio/Penguin, $32.95.) Two business journalists examine the financial crisis
PINHEADS AND PATRIOTS, by Bill O'Reilly. (Morrow/HarperCollins, $27.99.) The
Fox News commentator scrutinizes the meaning of change in the era of Obama.
THE EMPEROR OF ALL MALADIES, by Siddhartha Mukherjee. (Scribner, $30.)
An oncologist’s history of cancer and its treatment.
SH*T MY DAD SAYS, by Justin Halpern. (It Books/HarperCollins, $15.99.) A
coming-of-age memoir organized around the musings, purveyed on Twitter, of the
author’s father.
THE LAST BOY, by Jane Leavy. (Harper/HarperCollins, $27.99.) A biography of
the Yankees star Mickey Mantle, who grappled with a wrenching childhood and
